item.description: Of America's 100 largest cities, Boston currently ranks near dead last (94th) when it comes to the percentage of households with children. Yet cities offer great benefits for families, including proximity to cultural institutions and parks, a choice of transportation modes and diversity of housing and neighborhood services. As part of the "Designing a Livable City for Families" theme of Common Boston Weekend '09, a forum on "Cities for Families: Designing Boston for Every Generation" takes place on June 18 at 6:30 pm at the Quincy School in Chinatown (885 Washington Street). Speakers include Boston Globe columnist Tom Keane Hon. BSA, Boston Children's Museum president Lou Casagrande, Ground principal Shauna Gillies-Smith, urban design/planning consultant Susan Silberberg-Robinson, Zumix executive director Madeleine Steczynski and StoSS Landscape Urbanism principal Chris Reed. RSVP for this free talk to chinatown@commonboston.org.
item.name: Common Boston Forum: Designing Boston for Every Generation
